content.description: This route climbs the big, clean corner to the right of God-Stopper. Interesting stemming and jamming leads to the crux finger-sized crack. Fun and well-protected.
content.protection: A standard City rack will suffice.
content.location: Rappel from fixed anchor on the northwest corner of the Tower.

content.description: The 2016 Bingham guide is now clear on these routes and God-Stoppe ris the straight-in splitter. Unfortunately the rock quality at the start is not great, but protection is good. Climb the pockety handcrack past a detached flake and packrat nest to reach a short bit of wide hands. Arrange protection for a thin move up to the second horizontal and traverse right to the final thin crack. This crack gradually opens to hands, but pinches back down to a cruxy finish.
content.protection: Carry one blue camalot for the short wide-hands section, otherwise a standard selection of finger to hand-sized cams suffice.
content.location: Rappel from the fixed rap on the northwest corner.

content.description: All three Checkerboard Wall routes use the same approach (Left .10b. Center 5.9, Right 5.8). Climb a grainy crack that starts on the northeast corner of the rock (hard to get off the ground) to a nice ledge at the bottom of the Checkerboard (optional belay here). An airy traverse left leads to the Left option, or climb straight up to the Center crack or right to Right crack. The Left option climbs a short, very thin face to reach the arete, which it follows to the summit of the North Tower. The other two variations follow cracks and face to the summit.
content.protection: Thin gear for Left (stoppers, small cams), carry a 4 camalot for the Center, and standard rack for the Right.
content.location: Descend from two-bolt anchor on the northwest corner of the tower (awkward to start).
